author: @rebeccanascimento8234
text: This movie sucked me into the most enchanting atmosphere, encompassing my eyes to appreciate the art of gastronomy, cinema, and subtle acting until it moved me to tears at the sight of a dessert. The type of love story that is SO pure, so generous and so beautiful that it makes you feel hopeful. Beautiful ending too. Juliette Binoche is the Ultime dame of French cinema. My God, need to see it again to wash my eyes from the evils of today's world.

author: @truegrit7697
text: I just heard of this on NPR - it looks amazing.  I just love Juliette Binoche.  Apparently, no food-artists were used on this movie.  The director, a Chinese guy, worked closely with a French master to create foods that were shot in their natural forms, and that would look as they would in the 1800s - imperfect vegetables with the occasional spots, etc.  All food shots are natural.  I can't wait to watch this.

author: @ikenosis8160
text: I saw this last night. I absolutely loved it. It's a beautiful, gentle, subtle masterpiece. No giant sandworms making a ton of noise and nonsense. It's a movie about the power of love and the grace of being alive and the moments we get to share that make life magical and worth living. 10/10. Highly recommend.
